description: Bitcoin is the first cryptocurrency, created in 2009 by Satoshi Nakamoto. It's a decentralized currency not controlled by any government.
Ethereum is a blockchain that supports smart contracts. It's the foundation for many DeFi apps and NFTs.
A wallet stores your crypto. Can be software (like MetaMask) or hardware (like Ledger). Never share your seed phrase!
Any cryptocurrency that isn't Bitcoin is an altcoin — includes ETH, SOL, ADA, etc.
A blockchain is a public, decentralized ledger that records transactions across many computers so that records can't be altered retroactively.
Self-executing code on a blockchain that automatically enforces agreements when conditions are met.
Non-Fungible Token — a unique digital asset that represents ownership of digital or physical items like art, music, or real estate.
Fees paid to miners or validators to process and confirm transactions on a blockchain like Ethereum.
Decentralized Finance — financial services like lending, borrowing, and trading built on blockchains without intermediaries.
A cryptocurrency pegged to a stable asset like USD (e.g., USDT, USDC) to reduce volatility.
The process of validating blockchain transactions and earning rewards, often using powerful computers.
Locking up crypto to support a network and earn rewards in a Proof of Stake blockchain.
A platform (like Binance or Coinbase) where users can buy, sell, or trade cryptocurrencies.
A digital asset built on an existing blockchain, like ERC-20 tokens on Ethereum.
A digital record of all blockchain transactions. Each participant has access to an identical copy.
Decentralized Autonomous Organization — an entity governed by smart contracts and community voting, without centralized leadership.
A secret code that proves ownership of your crypto. Never share it with anyone.
A cryptographic code used to receive cryptocurrency — like your crypto email address.
A list of 12–24 words used to recover your wallet. Anyone with it can access your funds.
How easily an asset can be bought or sold without affecting its price.
A way to earn rewards by lending or staking crypto assets in DeFi protocols.
Free distribution of tokens to promote a project or reward loyal users.
Traditional government-issued currency like USD, EUR, or NGN.
Originally a typo for 'hold', now slang for holding crypto long-term regardless of market swings.
A person or entity that holds a large amount of cryptocurrency and can influence the market.
A market condition where prices are rising or expected to rise.
A market condition where prices are falling or expected to fall.
Decentralized Application — software that runs on a blockchain instead of centralized servers.
Initial Coin Offering — a fundraising method where new tokens are sold to investors.
Exponential Moving Average (20) — a technical indicator that gives more weight to recent prices, showing the average price over the last 20 periods with an emphasis on recent data.
Relative Strength Index — a momentum indicator that measures the speed and change of price movements to identify overbought or oversold conditions.
Moving Average Convergence Divergence — a trend-following indicator showing the relationship between two moving averages of a coin's price, often used to spot buy/sell momentum shifts.
Simple Moving Average — a basic moving average calculated by adding recent closing prices and dividing by the number of periods, giving equal weight to all data points.
Market Capitalization — the total value of a cryptocurrency calculated by multiplying the current price by the circulating supply.
All-Time High — the highest price a cryptocurrency has ever reached in its history.
All-Time Low — the lowest price a cryptocurrency has ever reached in its history.
A consensus mechanism where miners solve complex mathematical problems to validate transactions and secure the network, used by Bitcoin.
A consensus mechanism where validators are chosen to create new blocks based on the amount of crypto they hold and stake, used by Ethereum 2.0.
Scaling solutions built on top of existing blockchains to increase transaction speed and reduce fees, like Polygon and Arbitrum.
A split in the blockchain resulting in two separate versions, either planned (hard fork) or unplanned (soft fork).
The computational power used to mine and process transactions on a blockchain, measured in hashes per second.
An offline cryptocurrency wallet that stores private keys without internet connection, providing maximum security against hacks.
An online cryptocurrency wallet connected to the internet for easy access and transactions, but more vulnerable to attacks.
An event where the reward for mining new blocks is cut in half, occurring approximately every four years in Bitcoin to control supply.
Peer-to-Peer — direct transactions between users without intermediaries, the core principle of cryptocurrency networks.
A computer connected to a blockchain network that maintains a copy of the ledger and helps validate transactions.
Memory Pool — a waiting area for unconfirmed transactions before they are added to a block on the blockchain.
An uncollateralized loan in DeFi that must be borrowed and repaid within the same transaction block, often used for arbitrage.
The difference between the expected price of a trade and the actual executed price, common in low-liquidity markets.
The temporary loss of funds experienced when providing liquidity to DeFi pools due to price volatility between paired assets.
A scam where developers abandon a project and run away with investors' funds, common in new DeFi projects.
Centralized Exchange — a trading platform controlled by a company that acts as an intermediary, like Binance or Coinbase.
Decentralized Exchange — a trading platform that operates without a central authority, allowing direct peer-to-peer trading.
A tokenized version of a cryptocurrency that allows it to be used on a different blockchain, like WBTC (Wrapped Bitcoin) on Ethereum.
A service that provides external real-world data to smart contracts on the blockchain, like Chainlink.
The total amount of a cryptocurrency traded within a specific time period, indicating market activity and liquidity.
A charting method that displays the open, high, low, and close prices for a specific period, used in technical analysis.
A price level where buying pressure is strong enough to prevent the price from falling further.
A price level where selling pressure is strong enough to prevent the price from rising further.
A volatility indicator consisting of three lines: a middle moving average and upper/lower bands that expand and contract based on price volatility.
A technical analysis tool using horizontal lines to indicate areas of potential support or resistance at key Fibonacci levels.
A real-time list of buy and sell orders for a specific cryptocurrency on an exchange, showing market depth and liquidity.
An order to buy or sell cryptocurrency at a specific price or better, only executing when the market reaches that price.
An order to buy or sell cryptocurrency immediately at the best available current market price.
An automatic order that sells your cryptocurrency when it reaches a certain price to limit potential losses.
An automatic order that sells your cryptocurrency when it reaches a certain price to lock in gains.
The practice of buying cryptocurrency on one exchange where the price is lower and selling it on another where the price is higher for profit.
A manipulative scheme where a group artificially inflates a coin's price (pump) then sells at the peak, leaving late buyers with losses (dump).
Fear Of Missing Out — the anxiety that drives investors to buy during price rallies, often leading to poor investment decisions.
Fear, Uncertainty, and Doubt — negative information spread to influence perception and drive down cryptocurrency prices.
Know Your Customer — identity verification required by exchanges and platforms to comply with regulations and prevent fraud.
Anti-Money Laundering — regulations and procedures that crypto platforms use to prevent illegal financial activities.
Average True Range — a volatility indicator that measures the average range between high and low prices over a specific period.
A momentum indicator that compares a cryptocurrency's closing price to its price range over a specific period, identifying overbought or oversold conditions.
Commodity Channel Index — a momentum indicator that measures the current price level relative to an average price level over time.
Money Flow Index — a volume-weighted momentum indicator that uses both price and volume to identify overbought or oversold conditions.
Average Directional Index — a trend strength indicator that measures how strong a trend is, regardless of direction.
Volume Weighted Average Price — a trading benchmark that calculates the average price weighted by volume, showing the true average price.
A momentum indicator that measures overbought and oversold levels by comparing the closing price to the high-low range over a specific period.
Rate of Change — a momentum indicator that measures the percentage change in price between the current price and the price a certain number of periods ago.
On-Balance Volume — a cumulative volume-based indicator that shows buying and selling pressure by adding volume on up days and subtracting on down days.
A cryptocurrency with little to no value, utility, or credible development team, often created as a joke or scam.
A cryptocurrency based on internet memes or jokes, like Dogecoin or Shiba Inu, often driven by community hype rather than utility.
A period when altcoins outperform Bitcoin, typically characterized by significant price rallies across alternative cryptocurrencies.
Do Your Own Research — a reminder to independently verify information before making investment decisions rather than blindly following others.
An investor holding a cryptocurrency that has significantly decreased in value, often waiting for a price recovery that may never come.
A high-risk cryptocurrency investment with potential for massive returns, often referring to low-cap coins that could 'moon' or skyrocket in price.
The smallest unit of Bitcoin, equal to 0.00000001 BTC, named after Bitcoin's creator Satoshi Nakamoto.
The smallest unit of Ether (ETH), equal to 0.000000000000000001 ETH, used for gas fee calculations.
A denomination of Ether equal to 1 billion wei, commonly used to measure Ethereum gas prices.
The process by which all nodes in a blockchain network agree on the current state of the ledger and validate new transactions.
A data structure used in blockchains to efficiently and securely verify the integrity of large sets of data through cryptographic hashing.
A 'number only used once' in cryptographic mining that miners change repeatedly to find a valid hash meeting the difficulty requirement.
A measure of how hard it is to mine a new block on a blockchain, automatically adjusted to maintain consistent block creation times.
The exact date and time when a block was mined and added to the blockchain, creating an immutable chronological record.
A database that is consensually shared and synchronized across multiple locations without a central administrator.
A blockchain property meaning that once data is recorded, it cannot be altered or deleted, ensuring permanent record-keeping.
The practice of secure communication through mathematical algorithms, fundamental to blockchain security and cryptocurrency transactions.
A cryptographic function that converts input data into a fixed-size string of characters, used to secure blockchain data.
Secure Hash Algorithm 256-bit — the cryptographic hash function used by Bitcoin to secure transactions and mining.
Ethereum Request for Comment 20 — the technical standard for fungible tokens created on the Ethereum blockchain.
The technical standard for non-fungible tokens (NFTs) on the Ethereum blockchain, ensuring each token is unique.
The maximum amount of gas units you're willing to spend on an Ethereum transaction, preventing runaway costs.
The amount you're willing to pay per unit of gas for an Ethereum transaction, measured in gwei.
The permanent removal of cryptocurrency from circulation by sending it to an unusable wallet address, often to reduce supply.
The process of creating new cryptocurrency tokens or NFTs and adding them to the circulating supply.
A participant in a Proof of Stake network who validates transactions and creates new blocks in exchange for staking rewards.
A fixed time period in a blockchain network during which validators perform their duties, commonly used in Proof of Stake systems.
A Layer 2 scaling solution that processes transactions off-chain and posts summarized data to the main blockchain, reducing fees and increasing speed.
A separate blockchain that runs parallel to the main chain, allowing assets to move between chains while maintaining independence.
A protocol that connects two blockchains, allowing users to transfer assets and data between different networks.
Technology that enables interaction and asset transfers between different blockchain networks.
The ability of different blockchain networks to communicate, share data, and work together seamlessly.
The primary, fully functional blockchain network where real transactions occur with actual value, as opposed to test networks.
A separate blockchain network used by developers to test features and applications without risking real funds.
The very first block in a blockchain, hardcoded into the protocol and serving as the foundation for all subsequent blocks.
